The shooting mechanics are pretty good, though I have noticed there's a substantially larger amount of ways to create "orphans and widows" vs ways to take people alive and attempt to de-escalate situations. I'm not opposed to such gameplay - i.e. using cuffed civilians as ad-hoc battering rams, nondescript bad guys as godless heathens obstructing the path of my bullets, and 9mm pistols as less-lethal substitutes for taking in Quadamah alive - albeit in the most pain he's ever experienced in his split-life as a pizza delivery driver and leader of a terrorist cell.

With the DLC shifting more towards general counter-terrorism, and a lack of consequence for escalating tf out of any situation that the higher ups mistakenly deploy you and your mentally unstable goons to, the multiplayer can sometimes play closer to Insurgency coop with an arrest mechanic rather than a SWAT 4 successor. Unless you're going for S rank, which you really only need to do once to get anything significant out of it. 

Less-lethal and de-escalation is always an option, albeit one that is slower and in multiplayer, not really worth following through when the morale mechanic is absent. And even in SP, you can theoretically just replace your psychologically dysfunctional minions with an identically-skilled set of minions. I still prefer less-lethal regardless, because the gameplay is more engaging to me and there's been a lot of care put there. But asides from not giving my guys a mental breakdown, there isn't too much stopping me from shooting everybody and calling it a day, except for maybe yelling for compliance first.

Censorship is unfortunate. The fact that they were so quick to fold has me wonder initially how genuine they were being with the more extreme elements of their environmental story-telling. If you're selling me junk food, just tell me - I know what I'm in for.

 I will say- despite all that, there's still a good amount of authentic story-telling with these levels, and I'll always be vouching for that vision void are going for. I can also see how recreating SWAT 4's ROE and forcing the player to only go less-lethal, punishing them for not following through with a mandate of giving the suspect several hugs and words of affirmation before deciding to end their existence might translate to uniquely intense gameplay in sparing moments, but a 1:1 system would have you failing an entire mission if you make a single mistake - which can end up being more repetitive and frustrating for general audiences.

Hope to see more morally grey situations like "ends of the earth" where you have both a story and gameplay incentive (even if the latter is still very weak at this point) to not blast the ever-loving God out of each suspect that looks at you funny (uncuffed suspects included).

Ready or Not is one of the most intense and immersive tactical shooters imo. It nails the feeling of methodical, high-stakes room clearing in a way few games manage. Every mission demands patience, communication, and actual strategy-rush in, and the game will happily punish you for it.

The gunplay is weighty and grounded, suspect AI is unpredictable enough to keep you on edge, and the level design does a great job of making each entry feel tense. When things go right, it feels incredibly satisfying; when things go wrong, they go very wrong, and usually fast.

There‚Äôs a strong variety of scenarios, gear choices that actually matter, and regular updates that keep the experience fresh. Playing solo is intense but viable, though the game really shines with a coordinated group - this is a title that rewards teamwork as much as aim.

It‚Äôs not perfect. The difficulty can feel punishing to new players, AI teammates are functional but not always reliable, and performance can dip on certain maps. But despite the rough edges, the core gameplay loop is absolutely solid.

If you‚Äôre looking for a serious tactical shooter with an emphasis on planning, realism, and high tension, Ready or Not is one of the best out there.

* Has a good balance between authenticity and playability. It never collapses under the weight of hyper-realism, yet it never drifts into arcade territory either. It is a tactical shooter that feels grounded, and deliberate; without sacrificing the satisfaction of smooth gameplay.
* Recent updates have significantly elevated the game‚Äôs mechanics and gunplay.
* Investing more into enemy and civilian AI could push the experience toward excellence. The small quirks and inconsistencies in bot behavior may pull players out of the moment.

- Considering the rise of extraction shooters inspired by that genre (like ARC Raiders, or Escape From Tarkov), one can‚Äôt help but imagine what could be built if this game served as a foundation for a larger, more systemic project. An extraction-style survival shooter game featuring persistent loot, an inventory system, and player-driven trading could be incredible with Ready or Not's mechanics at its core. 

It feels like the next major trend is taking shape. And Ready or Not's tactical, realistic foundation make it one of the most promising candidates, should the developers ever decide to expand in that direction.

The tactical SWAT game Ready or Not is somewhat reminiscent of Rainbow Six 3, where tactical maneuvers are key to achieving your objective.

With good tactics and teamwork, you can navigate the maps fairly easily, but the S+ rank is only attainable if you avoid injuring enemies, which can be quite challenging at times.

The lack of a Workshop and new maps unfortunately makes the game repetitive after 15-20 hours, as you've completed all the maps. Replay value is rather limited. However, the existing maps are well-designed.

There are no official servers, so as the host, you have to wait for others to join the lobby, and it can take a while before the match actually starts. Naturally, you only play on the highest difficulty, Hard; anything else is pointless. Sometimes things go very smoothly, and you breeze through, while other times your teammates are killed by the first few enemies or caught off guard‚Äîit's all down to luck. There's usually no real coordination via voice chat; most of the time, players just charge in like Rambo (Leeroy Jeenkins style) and die.

If you just want to leisurely stroll through the maps and arrest or simply blast armed enemies, this game is perfect for you.
More thoughtful than a lot of FPS games, each combat encounter is like a puzzle with multiple tools at your disposal.

If you can get this for 20 or even 25$ hell even 30$ it is worth it, for those who love SWAT and Rainbow early instalments and love methodical room clearing and tactical strategy this is for you, especially if you love a good challenge would recommend for those interested in police sims, mil sims, and FPS, or strategy games.

The official VR mod for this is jank af but still playable. 

1) You have to use the desktop for most menus. When the game has started, press 'U' to enter VR.

2) If you use the respawn mod, press 'Home' before pressing 'U' after you die, otherwise you will be floating 10 feet above your character's head.

3) A lot of guns don't have proper reloading/chambering. Like the G3 you can manually reload but you can't chamber it so it fires without being chambered, the P90 can't be reloaded so it just fires without a magazine. You'll have to figure these things out on a gun-by-gun basis.

4) Throwing nades is a nightmare in VR. They almost always fall at your feet.

5) Having the orders on click right stick is dumb. I'm trying to keep a bead on the suspect while shouting orders and my aim keeps shifting because I have to click the right stick.

6) Your avatar doesn't follow your headset 100% exactly, it sort of lags behind a little bit, which means you can't always grab things from your weapon/ammo slots without looking. Sometimes they aren't aligned the way you expect them to be.

There are some other issues but those are the main ones. I'd give this a neutral rating, if I could. Overall, it's fun when it works but super, super jank. If you're getting it for VR, make sure you grab it on sale and thoroughly test it before your 2 hour/15 day refund window is up because you might find it unplayable.

Ready or Not Review ‚Äî 9/10 (Tactical Chaos at Its Finest)

Ready or Not is the kind of tactical shooter that makes your palms sweat, your heart pound, and your squad yell ‚ÄúDON‚ÄôT OPEN THAT DOOR‚ÄîWAIT‚ÄîFLASHBANG‚ÄîNOOOO!‚Äù right before everything explodes into total disaster. And honestly? It‚Äôs incredible.

This game nails tension like almost nothing else in the genre. You‚Äôre leading an elite SWAT team through high-risk missions where every decision matters. One wrong move and the whole operation falls apart. One perfect breach, and you feel like a tactical genius straight out of a Hollywood thriller.

The gunplay is heavy and realistic‚Äîfiring a weapon feels powerful and dangerous, forcing you to think before pulling the trigger. Hostage encounters are nerve-wracking, suspects are unpredictable, and the atmosphere is so intense that even opening a closet feels like defusing a bomb.

But the real magic happens in co-op. Planning room entries, stacking on doors, calling out suspects, accidentally flashbanging your own squad‚Äîit‚Äôs serious, but it‚Äôs also hilariously unforgettable. Every mission becomes a story worth retelling.

The maps are detailed and immersive, ranging from cramped apartments to massive public spaces, and the game constantly pushes you to adapt and communicate. It rewards patience and teamwork instead of running-and-gunning.

Is it perfect? Not quite. AI can be weird sometimes, there are occasional bugs, and the steep learning curve might scare off casual players. But when Ready or Not is in full motion, it delivers some of the most intense and satisfying tactical gameplay you can find today.

Pros

Ultra-tense tactical gameplay with realistic gun handling

Deep teamwork and communication focus

Amazing atmosphere and detailed environments

Missions that always feel dangerous and unpredictable

Cons

Can be brutally difficult for new players

Occasional bugs and AI oddities

Verdict:
A heart-pounding, tactical masterpiece that turns every mission into a cinematic, stressful, unforgettable experience. If you love strategy, teamwork, and realism, this game is a must-play.

I'm also not a fan of the fact that, in order to get an S rating, terrorists who have just shot hundreds of civilians in a nightclub and then point their weapons at me have to be arrested. For a shooter that claims to be realistic, this is somehow strange (or are the developers unaware of the bodycam footage in which police officers empty their entire magazine into people because they are walking towards them with a knife?).

All in all, it's still a very good game. Would buy again.

The core of the game is fun. Graphics are immersive, gunfights are tense, sound design is quite good. If you have a bunch of friends that'll run multiplayer missions with you, there's almost nothing to complain about.

Well, the suspect AI is incredibly simple. Suspects rarely try to flee, sometimes they see you with their backs turned from the entire corridor while you're sneaking, and they might decide not to surrender when surrounded by five officers and being pumped by beanbags and pepperballs.

Then there's equipment jankiness. Interrupting shotgun reloads or even weapon switching seems not possible, so I was once stuck loading 6 shells before being able to switch to a taser. Also, not taking any magazines for a weapon means you'll have it with an empty magazine inside. Why even take it for the mission then at all???

And don't get me started on squad AI. Sometimes they'll restrain suspects automatically, for which I'm thankful in a room with 4 surrendered suspects where any of them might decide to pull a gun on me anyway. But sometimes they'll start restraining automatically in a middle of a corridor 2 seconds after being shot at. Or they'll restrain a civilian instead, and get surprised by a suspect faking surrender 2 meters behind them. Or they won't bag the evidence, because why would they. Or the AI will get stuck on a command like "Open, flash and clear". Or they'll decide to go around to the other side of the door and get absolutely blasted. Or the AI will refuse to use the shield, even though their primary weapon purposefully has no ammunition. Or it will kill a suspect with a beanbag, forcing you to restart the mission just because. Or they will disobey a "Restrain" command to engage with a suspect, even though there are 4 other officers already engaging him, which gets us surprised by that one surrendered suspect. The squad accuracy and adherence to Rules of Engagement is also atrocious - sometimes they'll engage immediately, sometimes they'll wait before 5 JHP rounds are firmly logged in their chests. Sometimes they can hit center of mass, sometimes they'll pump 3 rounds into a wall in front of them because their wallhack told them to.

The game can be quite fun and getting S ranks feels rewarding, but it would be a much more pleasant experience without all the jank.

They completely broke this game.

I bought the Ready or Not LSPD bundle with all the DLC's on sale about a month or so before the major censorship changes. When I say they COMPLETELY broke the game, I mean it. All of my game files are the ones included with the game; nothing extra from mods. Additionally, I have gone through Vortex and removed mods + the archives from there, as well as manually going through the files and checking to make sure that no mods are there. This was a COMPLETELY STOCK installation, and it kept popping up with "Corrupt data found, please verify your installation". At this point, I had already verified at least 3 times, each time double and triple checking my game files.

On top of this, when it would actually allow me to play my game shortly after the censorship changes, all of the mods were broken entirely, which was expected, but it seemed like it was less mod friendly this time, almost. Albeit mod.io is officially a menu option in-game that you can install mods through, the Nexus mods are almost entirely, if not entirely, broken. Not to mention, the other following issues, but not limited to:

-Major graphical changes, as well as gore and NSFW being removed that they initially said would be there in the commitment to make the game as true to what happens with law enforcement as possible, although it can be added back with mods,
-The community manager being fired for making controversial comments on a now dead figure that was catastrophic to a lot of America,
-Changes, such as breaking AI and downgrading a lot of components of the game that was loved JUST to make it able to be ran on console,
-And continuing to be mostly inactive with the community, to the point where it feels like it's almost been shut-out.

For context, I very, very rarely post negative reviews, in fact, I believe this is my first negative review, if not my second at most, due to what these developers have done to this game. Before, I loved it; no issue with the genre itself, and then the greed came along and ruined it.

Fine as a first-person shooter, terrible as a police simulator. Real-world departments have a use-of-force continuum that ends with lethal force. This game allows you to fire warning shots (lethal force) to encourage compliance from nonthreatening civilians but penalizes players for firing on an armed terrorist holding a hostage without shouting for compliance first (verbal contact, the second lowest rung on the ladder).

This is obviously a project by European computer developers imagining being American cops made with no outside input. Which is fine. Here, strung-out drug addicts have ten thousand dollar automatic weapons, nightclubs are grimy neon dance floors and EDM but also water play dungeons, and furious doctors demand to be allowed help a wounded terrorist who just murdered their coworkers. VOID took a cargo cult approach to creativity, daydreaming about an imaginary world seen only in TV shows and YouTube videos. Which is, again, fine.

Regarding the actual gameplay itself, it's okay. Computer games are a series of interesting decisions; single-player scoring restricts the player's choice too significantly for this to be considered a game. You cease to be an officer and are reduced to a helpless witness, watching a squad of algorithms as they simulate shooting paintballs at an armed child molester. Multiplayer, especially mods, are where the game allows the player personal liberty to play as they choose.

The game has fallen so upsettingly far from everything it was meant to be and express. The upsetting and horrible nature of the things encountered and done should be upsetting and make you uncomfortable and upset. That's the reality of the horror of these difficult subjects and situations in life the game was meant to be commentary on. The game had done a great job of trying to showcase the terrible decisions and actions officers at times have to make and suffer from while not actually becoming pure "copaganda"  just blindly defending the many horrible flaws and problems in the law enforcement world. At every turn it's an amazing piece of environmental storytelling to paint the bleak struggling world on the brink of collapse and how law enforcement can only ever be an after the fact bandage for a problem that must be addressed in society. Law enforcement cannot solve poverty, mental health, systemic exploitation, and desperation. It shows how these things hurt everyone including the officers themselves as you see and hear the declining mental state of the officers around you and how these wider problems plus policy and culture within law enforcement can enable and push good officers that truly want to help the lives of those around them into corruption and failure. I can't think of any other game anything remotely similar that actually elicits this sort of emotional response and thought on these things in life and it's truly very sad seeing how more and more it keeps heading towards being another Call of Duty lacking any soul. Remember that videogames are a form of art and art is political. It always has been and probably always will be.

The game is fun, and hard. If you can play with friends, and use good communication and tactics, its very good. Playing with the AI teammates is infuriating. They will walk directly in front of you, block you out of cover, get in the way of engaging enemies while you are actively being shot at, then tell you that you are in their way. If I could turn them off entirely, or turn off collision, and they stayed behind me unless I specifically order them to, the game would be massively improved.
The enemy AI is massively improved from what it would be, but I have been killed many, many times while getting good hits on the enemy, and they just ignore the hits. There's no reason my character, wearing full ceramic plate armor, should be more affected by gun shots than someone wearing just a hoodie, while they are being shot in the chest with hollow points.
The devs also don't seem to respond to the community any more. Looking through the community page here, they seem to have disappeared. After they censored the PC version after swearing they would never compromise their vision for the game, that's probably the smart move.
There isn't another game in the genre worth playing right now, but I can't recommend this game if you don't have a dedicated group to play with.

This game is ruined by the AI in two different flavors.

Flavor 1 Your Teammates: The AI teammates are about as useful as a wet piece of toilet paper. When they aren't getting out gunned by run of the mill crackheads with an elevation advantage as well as shooting first; they are standing in locations that open them up to enemy fire and the best part is...they will sit there, get shot and die. They operate on a similar wavelength of Reese in the Malcolm in the Middle episode where he joins the Army. "...I don't know how to feel sir, I am waiting for you to tell me." They will do literally nothing without you telling them first, including measures that will save their own lives.

Flavor 2 The Enemy: Do not mistake this as me saying the AI is too hard. What makes them a pain is how unfair they are to fight against. They will literally shoot you through walls because they caught sight of a single pixel of your player model. They also all attended the Sam Fisher academy of stealthy movement, because they will hardly make any noise at all, if any. Furthermore, the player is very hamstrung mobility wise, which I am fine with, it is supposed to be a tactical shooter and I get that. But do not subject me to the most glacial movement system known to man and give the AI Battlefield levels of movement ability. They are able to run, strafe, and shoot all together in one fluid motion and this doesn't affect their ability to land shots whatsoever. Lastly, suppression, the player gets shot at and my vision cones enough to make me effectively blind. However, enemy AI gets shot at and it's as if you just farted in their general direction.

Overall, I have tried this game many times over the past year or so. And each time I remind myself of why I stopped playing. The bones are there, the gameplay is there, its just the AI is so horrific in a game that revolves around it, I cannot recommend it. 

P.S. The whole censorship thing is another huge issue I have with the game, but that is mostly down to the developers being spineless bastards and chasing money rather than staying loyal to the core idea of their game.

Well, good idea but imo a very annoying implementation.
This game (similar to Arma) shows very well how realism doesn't lead to fun. Compared to other shooters leaning towards realism, this one is even more annoying, because it (in many ways) only includes realism in ways that clash with the promised fantasy of the game. 

For example:
- You can't shoot to disable. Like shooting in the foot. In fact, shooting someone in the foot or leg will most often (or always) not even count as a hit.
- Several possible reactions of enemies are very far from what any human would do. Sure, unpredictable humans are realistic humans, but I mean unpredictable in the AI kind of sense.

It's also technically annoying, actually. After ever mission in coop, all people have to quit and rejoin the session to be able to use their main intel gathering device. All animations are quite slow, with even slower fades in-between them. At least restarting a mission is somewhat fast.

This "realistic" game is not realistic at all, dogshit AI.

Edit: Beat the game on hard mode - lethal, and as a 'pro' now i can say that the game is not hard, just bullshit a lot of the times

In short:
A cool game that gets ruined by its greedy pricing and is partly hurt by censorship to a lesser extent.  Buy a key somewhere or find other ways to play don't fund something that asks for so much for so little.

long version:
A while fun and somewhat polished games their is a fair chunk of issues I don't like that makes me not recommend this game.
mainly the following:

-The damn pricing this game has is plain old silly. You have to pay 50 usd for a game that feels only half complete at times (I run into a decent chunk of bugs or issues even through its supposed to be a "complete game") along with the content and replay ability being relatively short and increasing the price for the game after adding a couple of minor things and calling it "complete" is also really silly many other games can offer the bang for your buck for way less than this.

-Also adding overpriced dlc (10 usd) for a already pricey game is further silly and greedy especially with the fact you disabled family sharing because you have to nickel and dime in any way possible I guess (I played a couple of the dlc levels with a friend who bought them and even they agreed the price is dumb non of the content is worth it at all and could have just been free updates). 

-The A.I in this game is the also a significant issue when I mention bugs earlier. The swat A.I is as smart as a brick they'll constantly sit in place and get shot,ignore your commands and every now and again just play stupid in other ways not mentioned here that gets you killed or themselves killed. The suspects do have a way better A.I through but there is definitely situations were they also feel wonky or just plain old dumb. 

-Also because of the single player feeling wonky the game is ten folds more fun with others but good luck convincing a friend to get a game for such a giant price and this also even more a issue for a game that only itches a niche for only a few. people

-A more minor one but one I do want to mention (but is far from a main or core point for this review) is the forced censorship. There is definitely in someway to make a toggle setting and the devs just don't want to bother and while again minor some of the specific changes are really odd and or remove part of the tone of the levels. The main 2 ones in specific cases that really piss me off is the valley of dolls on console and the sleeping kid. Both don't make sense and hurt the tone of a game that supposed to represent real world situations. It also makes it even harder to connect to these or take these situations seriously when your hit with a nonsensical censored replacement for what would've been a surprising moment that makes the situation feel more grounded. It also rubs me the wrong way because if there fine with changing there vision for a companies what stops them from further changing or neutering things (while sure they might not or say they wont its hard to trust them end of the day if they already did it promise or not promised)

(also on this last point I would heavily recommend you form your own opinion and or views as this part is more opinionated and or situational aka do your own research make your own opinion. I'm expressing my personal opinion on this subject because its still a valid issue to the game to mention that I think is critical to a extent. )

This game's early trailers hyped up so many features and cool things, that never made it into the game.
The game advertised itself as taking the tactical and strategic side of SWAT 4 and pushing it to the next level with many more tools, and pushing realism and attention to detail to the next level.
Yet, from early access to release, the game never ended up having from what I can tell, ANY of the features they advertised, that would've been a huge innovation over SWAT 4.

What we have now instead, is, just a game that innovated nothing over its predecessors. It has some nice polish, QOL stuff, better animations and graphics, yeah, sure. That's nice and all... But, there's so much stuff that just doesn't exist.
All the things around pre-planning and many different ways to approach situations? Simply not there.
Drones, ladders, shutting the power off, picking entry points and strategies? Nothing
The cinematic cutscenes of things like the watching your team arrive to places, which would give an immersive feeling and in turn uplifts the story and character development and named characters they talked about? Doesn't exist at all. You just go from level to level, loading screen to loading screen. Sure, that's how SWAT was, but, they advertised the above in the trailers, and didn't deliver.


And then top that off with the fact that, they actually went back and started removing things that were in early access, and, then after release, they went and censored a bunch of stuff to make it all safe for console release...
Yeah... No. Its not a bad game, but its existence can hardly be justified when it feels like it barely if at all moves forward on SWAT 4 aside from graphically. Mostly, the changes are not flat improvements, but, changes that someone may simply find preferable, or not so. Alterations to the game formula, rather than additions. All for a price significantly higher, and PC requirements that are also so.

***Be in mind that this comment is from 27.11.2025 The game features might have changed by then***

It somehow still feels extremely early access. Like it's missing alot of key quality of life and gameplay features. There's no tutorial and you're just thrown into the game and expected to understand and pick up all of the random control methods (issuing commands to Gold Team, Blue Team etc, how to change weapon loadouts, how to manage the team, where to go in the police HQ etc.)

The missions are really uninspired and the AI is terrible. The baddies will just stand in their same pre-programmed spots on the map and will never move. The mission goals are always the same (go in, kill baddies, don't kill goodies, leave). Often I'd complete a mission and there'd be no indication that I still had more baddies to kill or where I was supposed to go, or that I was done and had to leave. There should be some form of HUD notifications guiding you better or something like someone from HQ saying 'Good work boys, that's everything. Head back". They should give you an option to leave the normal way or just press escape or something to instantly leave the map.

The lack of gamemode variety sucks as well. You've got all these weapon choices but you only get to use it against garbage AI in only a handful of developer maps. Why can't we have an option for PVP or something like you VS another enemy AI squad. There's even mods for this. Why can't this be in the base game?

Ultimately a big let down as they never reached any peaks with this and just wasted the opportunity for an actually realistic tacticool shooter. It doesn't have to be another Battlefield or Call of Duty but come on, you guys spend all this effort getting voice acting and realistic gunz but can't design a fun game?
